pr_title: Consent Mgmt Service - Replace transaction commit/rollback with @Transactional

timeline.bodyText: It doesn't seem like this is strictly necessary, spring-boot-data seems like it does this for you https://stackoverflow.com/a/41643269
timeline.author: nikklassen
nikklassen

replies.bodyText: Some of the tests were failing so we needed to fix them. We implemented Cloud Storage mock in Participant Manager so we've refactored the code to follow same approach here.
replies.author: dhanyak-btc

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't these annotations be on the Dao class? That way you add them in one place instead of everywhere that the Dao is used
timeline.author: nikklassen

replies.bodyText:
I checked SO post Where should “@Transactional” be place Service Layer or DAO
We should add @Transactional in Service layer.
replies.author: dhanyak-btc

replies.bodyText:
You also see on that post.

There are a lot of CRUD applications that don't have any significant business logic, for them having a service layer that just passes stuff through between the controllers and data access objects is not useful. In these cases we can put transaction annotation on Dao.

It's really just a judgement call of where your logical transactions exist. Either way is fine here I guess, I just wanted to highlight that this isn't a hard rule.
replies.author: nikklassen
